learning_outcomes.description: Understand and apply practical music production techniques including recording, sampling, synthesis, and mixing, combing Digital Audio Workstation software with hardware such as microphones, audio interfaces, and controllers.
Understand core conceptual and theoretical concepts that relate to the recording and manipulation of sound.
Work creatively with others by collaborating, listening, sharing, and providing and receiving peer feedback.
Navigate the conception, production, and release of a substantial independent creative project.
Understand current industry practices related to releasing, distributing, and promoting music.

assessments.due_date:
Practical Project 1 16/03/2026 - 20/03/2026

Practical Project 2 30/03/2026 - 3/04/2026

Practical Project 3 20/04/2026 - 24/04/2026

Must be completed during the scheduled Laboratory Session as per the timetable provided.
assessments.task_description:
Practical Projects are in-class tasks which focus on a particular aspect of music production. They are designed to encourage practical learning whilst also assessing developing skills.

Practical Projects are short, focused, and contained, and are designed to develop the skills necessary for completing the final Major Production Project.

Practical Projects are completed in regular class time with assistance from the teacher. At the beginning of class, students will be provided with the information or files necessary to complete the task, and must complete and submit before the end of class. See Blackboard for details on this assessment task. All the knowledge and skills required to complete the task will be provided in advance via tutorials and lectures, and students will have an opportunity to practice the skills both in-class and independently.

PLEASE NOTE: GENERATIVE AI

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission will occur during scheduled class time, according to submission instructions provided on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Absence during an in-class assessment without medical or other documentation will result in a score of 0 for the missed project. If a project is missed for legitimate personal or medical reasons, and documentation is provided, an extension can be granted. In this case, it is the student's responsibility to apply for an extension and liaise with the tutor to arrange a suitable time to re-sit the task.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The Major Project is a significant creative work, created individually outside of class time. Within some prescribed parameters (e.g. duration, minimum number of tracks, etc), it allows students flexibility to explore genres, techniques, and ideas which are of personal interest. The major project is an opportunity for students to apply knowledge and skills learnt throughout the semester within an individually meaningful musical context.

The Major Project is due at 5pm on Friday of Week 12 (22/05/2026), with a compulsory draft feedback session during the Week 9 tutorial.

Draft Feedback Session

Students will present a significant work-in-progress draft to their tutorial class in Week 9, and will receive feedback from the tutor and peers. Presentation of the draft and participation in the feedback session is a pass/fail hurdle requirement for the Major Project Assessment Item. That means, your draft is not graded, but you must present and participate in order to pass the Major Project item as a whole.

Final Project Submission

Students will submit their final project online on Friday 22/05.2026 by 5pm. Submission must include:

  • Exported WAV file of the final track
  • All working project files
  • Incremental backups showing progress
  • A project info sheet including information about sample sources, techniques, and the creative process (template provided on Blackboard).


Students will be required to keep incremental backups of their work-in-progress, and document any use of third-party samples, third party plug-ins, or musical source material that is not completely original.

Detailed information about the Major Project will be posted on Blackboard. 

PLEASE NOTE: GENERATIVE AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed technical understanding of their production work independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Draft must be presented in class in Week 9.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Create an 800-word written release plan for the commercial/public release of your Major Project work.

Using the template provided, draw on lecture content, readings, and your own research related to current music industry practices and music release strategies to create a clear, concise, and actionable plan for release.

Because the work you produced for the Major Project is unique, your release strategy will also be unique. It will be tailored to the style, context, and strengths of your Major Project work, and to your own developing identity as an artist.

Your release plan must be:

  • realistic - taking advantage of current and local opportunities, using a budget of no more than $800.
  • practical - clear and detailed enough to guide day-to-day work on the release. The overarching strategy is digested into actionable tasks.
  • holistic - including plans for mastering, administration, disctribution, and promotion of the release.


PLEASE NOTE: GENERATIVE AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
